title: DANL Project
section: 2.2 MPG and a Type of Cars
text:
2.2 MPG and a Type of Cars
The following boxplot shows how the distribution of highway MPG (hwy) varies by a type of cars (class) ğŸš™ ğŸšš ğŸš.

ggplot(data = mpg) +
  geom_boxplot(aes(x = class, y = hwy, fill = class),
               show.legend = F) +
  labs(x = "Class", y = "Highway\nMPG")

title: danl200-hw5-Sun-Jeremy
text:
##Q1A
#Github repository link https://github.com/jws14/jws14.github.io

library(skimr)
library(tidyverse)

â”€â”€ Attaching core tidyverse packages â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€ tidyverse 2.0.0 â”€â”€
âœ” dplyr     1.1.3     âœ” readr     2.1.4
âœ” forcats   1.0.0     âœ” stringr   1.5.0
âœ” ggplot2   3.4.3     âœ” tibble    3.2.1
âœ” lubridate 1.9.3     âœ” tidyr     1.3.0
âœ” purrr     1.0.2     
â”€â”€ Conflicts â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€ tidyverse_conflicts() â”€â”€
âœ– dplyr::filter() masks stats::filter()
âœ– dplyr::lag()    masks stats::lag()
â„¹ Use the conflicted package (<http://conflicted.r-lib.org/>) to force all conflicts to become errors

library(ggplot2)
library(dplyr)

##Q2

NFL2022_stuffs <- read_csv('https://bcdanl.github.io/data/NFL2022_stuffs.csv')

Rows: 50147 Columns: 10
â”€â”€ Column specification â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€
Delimiter: ","
chr (2): game_id, posteam
dbl (8): play_id, drive, week, qtr, down, half_seconds_remaining, pass, wp

â„¹ Use `spec()` to retrieve the full column specification for this data.
â„¹ Specify the column types or set `show_col_types = FALSE` to quiet this message.


##Q2A

NFL2022_stuffs <-  NFL2022_stuffs %>% 
  filter(!is.na(posteam))

##Q2B

summary_data <-  NFL2022_stuffs %>% 
  filter(wp > .2 & wp < .75,
         down <=2,
         half_seconds_remaining > 120) %>% 
  group_by(posteam) %>% 
  summarize(mean_pass = mean(pass, na.rm = TRUE))

##Q2C

summary_graph <- summary_data %>% 
  mutate(posteam = reorder(posteam, mean_pass))

ggplot(summary_graph, aes(x= mean_pass, y = posteam)) +
  geom_point() 




##Q2D

NFL2022_epa <- read_csv('https://bcdanl.github.io/data/NFL2022_epa.csv')

Rows: 46427 Columns: 7
â”€â”€ Column specification â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€
Delimiter: ","
chr (4): game_id, posteam, receiver, passer
dbl (3): play_id, drive, epa

â„¹ Use `spec()` to retrieve the full column specification for this data.
â„¹ Specify the column types or set `show_col_types = FALSE` to quiet this message.

NFL2022_stuffs_EPA <-  bind_cols( NFL2022_stuffs, NFL2022_epa %>% 
                                    select(passer, receiver, epa))
NFL2022_stuffs_EPA <-  NFL2022_stuffs_EPA %>% 
  filter(!is.na(passer))

##Q2E

passer_data <-  NFL2022_stuffs_EPA %>% 
  filter(passer %in% c( "J.Allen", "P.Mahomes"))
mean_epa <-  passer_data %>% 
  group_by( week, passer) %>% 
  summarize(mean_epa = mean(epa, na.rm = TRUE))

`summarise()` has grouped output by 'week'. You can override using the
`.groups` argument.

ggplot(passer_data, aes(x = week, y = epa, color = passer)) +
  geom_line() +
  scale_color_manual(values = c("J.Allen" = 'blue', "P.Mahomes"
                                = 'red'))




##Q2F

spread_data <- mean_epa %>% 
  spread(passer, mean_epa)
spread_data <- spread_data %>% 
  mutate(diff_JALLEN_PMAHOME = J.Allen - P.Mahomes)

title: Welcome To My Blog
text:
This is the first post in a Quarto blog. Welcome!

Since this post doesnâ€™t specify an explicit image, the first image in the post will be used in the listing page of posts.

title: Jeremy Sun
text:
oj <- read_csv('https://bcdanl.github.io/data/dominick_oj.csv')

Rows: 28947 Columns: 4
â”€â”€ Column specification â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€
Delimiter: ","
chr (1): brand
dbl (3): sales, price, ad

â„¹ Use `spec()` to retrieve the full column specification for this data.
â„¹ Specify the column types or set `show_col_types = FALSE` to quiet this message.

nvars <- format(round(ncol(oj), 0), 
                nsmall=0, 
                big.mark=",") 
nobs <- format(round(nrow(oj), 0), 
                nsmall=0, 
                big.mark=",")


Here is the paged table using rmarkdown::paged_table() with the results = 'asis' chunk option.




  



theme_set(theme_ipsum()+
          theme(strip.background =element_rect(fill="lightgray"),
                axis.title.x = 
                  element_text(angle = 0,
                               size = rel(1.33),
                               margin = margin(10,0,0,0)),
                axis.title.y = 
                  element_text(angle = 0,
                               size = rel(1.33),
                               margin = margin(0,10,0,0))
                )
          )


billboard <- read_csv('https://bcdanl.github.io/data/billboard.csv')

Rows: 317 Columns: 81
â”€â”€ Column specification â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€
Delimiter: ","
chr   (2): artist, track
dbl  (66): year, wk1, wk2, wk3, wk4, wk5, wk6, wk7, wk8, wk9, wk10, wk11, wk...
lgl  (11): wk66, wk67, wk68, wk69, wk70, wk71, wk72, wk73, wk74, wk75, wk76
date  (1): date.entered
time  (1): time

â„¹ Use `spec()` to retrieve the full column specification for this data.
â„¹ Specify the column types or set `show_col_types = FALSE` to quiet this message.

rmarkdown::paged_table(billboard)



  



##Q!A
â€“Describe how the distribution of rating varies across week 1, week 2, and week 3 using the faceted histogram.

ggplot(billboard) +
  geom_histogram(aes(x= wk1))

`stat_bin()` using `bins = 30`. Pick better value with `binwidth`.






Wit Facet

q1a <- billboard %>% 
  pivot_longer(col = wk1:wk76,
               names_to = "week",
               values_to = "rating" ) %>% 
  filter(week %in% c('wk1','wk2','wk3' ) )  

##Q1B
â€“Which artist(s) have the most number of tracks in billboard data.frame?
â€“Do not double-count an artistâ€™s tracks if they appear in multiple weeks.
##Q2A
â€“Make ny_pincp longer.
##Q2B
â€“Provide both (1) ggplot code and (2) a simple comment to describe how overall the yearly trend of NY countiesâ€™ average personal incomes are.
##Q3A â€“Keep only the following three variables, date, countriesAndTerritories, and cases.
Then make a wide-form data.frame of covid whose variable names are from countriesAndTerritories and values are from cases.
Then drop the variable date.
##Q3B
Use the wide-form data.frame of covid to find the top 10 countries in terms of the correlation between their cases and the USA case. Use cor(data.frame), which returns a matrix. Then convert it to data.frame using as.data.frame(matrix)

title: Starwars 2
text:
Letâ€™s analyze the starwars data:
starwars <- read_csv("https://bcdanl.github.io/data/starwars.csv")

title: Starwars 2
text:
Variable Description for starwars data.frame
The following describes the variables in the starwars data.frame.

films List of films the character appeared in
name Name of the character
species Name of species
height Height (cm)
mass Weight (kg)
hair_color, skin_color, eye_color Hair, skin, and eye colors
birth_year Year born (BBY = Before Battle of Yavin)
sex The biological sex of the character, namely male, female, hermaphroditic, or none (as in the case for Droids).
gender The gender role or gender identity of the character as determined by their personality or the way they were programmed (as in the case for Droids).
homeworld Name of homeworld

title: Starwars 2
text:
Human vs.Â Droid

ggplot(data = 
         starwars %>% 
         filter(species %in% c("Human", "Droid"))) +
  geom_boxplot(aes(x = species, y = mass, 
                   fill = species),
               show.legend = FALSE)

title: Jeremy Sun
text: Jeremy Sun majors in Data Analytics at SUNY Geneseo. When not working on data analytics, Jeremy enjoys spending time listening to music and drawing anything that comes to mind.

title: Jeremy Sun
text:
Education
State University of New York at Geneseo | Geneseo, NY  B.S. in Data Analytics | Aug 2022 - May 2026  Minor in Business Administration

title: Jeremy Sun
text:
Experience
Starbucks Analytics | Data Analyst Intern | May 2024 - Aug 2024
